text:
When recording via the HTTP Proxy Server I find my sequence correctly recorded
except some request have missing parameters. Also the parameters are recorded in
the wrong order.

Parameters are lost when I have many of the same name, especially when some of
them have the same value. Also parameters are not recorded in the correct order.
And parameters that have no value are also lost. To some it might seem silly to
have many parameters of the same name and the same value or with no value so
I'll explain.

My application is well tried and tested under many browsers, so I believe the
behaviour I expect is legitimate. The form in question consists of a matrix of
values, I send them in sequence. So for a 3 x 4 matrix I might send:

matrix.html?update=yes&d=1&d=2&d=&d=&d=&d=&d=&d=1&d=2&d=1&d=&d=

To know the position of values in my matrix it is important to send the
parameters which have the same name, same value, blank ones and to preserve the
correct order.

My experiments suggest that this needs correcting for the proxy server, for data
entry and for saving to disk.

I've also noticed that a request parameter of action=Login >> looses the space
between Login and >>.

Hope this information is sufficient.

Regards,
Pete Hargreaves

P.S. Jmeter is otherwise BRILLIANT thankyou.
creator: pdh@totalise.co.uk

text:
After tracing these arguments through at least 13 different classes, I've found
they end up being merged into an empty collection by the 'value instanceof
Collection' case of AbstractTestElement.mergeIn(TestElement).

This same merging operation is occuring before saving the test plan. I don't
know why, but that's how it is.

The way this merging is implemented guarantees all elements in the result
collection will be unique.

- I don't know in which cases this merging operation is actually used (not only
merging against an empty collection).
- I don't know why it ends up being invoked in those two cases.
- I don't know why HTTP Arguments needs to be TestElement and go through all
this pain.

Anyone knowing please drop me a word.

I'll give it a crack, but will mostly be trial-and-error, I guess...
creator: jsalvata@atg.com
